channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Palestinian Authority Leader’s Visit Highlights Turkey’s Unique Role in Gaza Conflict
item.description: Turkish officials have bashed Israel and praised Hamas, complicating their country’s place in diplomacy aimed at ending the war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Portraits of Survival: The Israeli Hostages Who Made It Home
item.description: They are now trying to rebuild their lives, campaign for the return of the hostages still in Gaza and mourn for those who were killed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Fumio Kishida, Japan’s Prime Minister, Will Step Down in September
item.description: The unpopular prime minister is bowing to pressure within his party. But it is unclear whether the party is truly ready to choose a candidate who will meet the public’s concerns.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis, Hisako Ueno and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan after a news conference in Tokyo on Wednesday. Mr. Kishida has been Japan’s prime minister since 2021.

item.title: UK Asylum Seekers Are Still on Edge After the Far-Right Riots
item.description: Abdulmoiz, an asylum seeker from Sudan, feared for his life when far-right rioters tried to set fire to the hotel where he was housed. The violence has eased, but he is still afraid.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Danny Lawson/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The police faced off with crowds during an anti-immigration riot this month at a Holiday Inn Express near the town of Rotherham, England.

item.title: Russia Begins Moving Some Troops From Ukraine to Repel Kyiv’s Offensive
item.description: Russia has begun moving some troops from Ukraine to deal with a Ukrainian incursion, the U.S. and Ukraine say. But Moscow appears reluctant to withdraw units from hot spots in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military vehicle passing a roadside crater minutes after a Russian strike near the border in Ukraine’s Sumy region on Tuesday.

item.title: Thai Premier Srettha Removed From Office on Ethics Charges
item.description: Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin was considered a figurehead leader in a behind-the-scenes power struggle. He was ousted on ethics charges.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin of Thailand at a news conference in Bangkok on Wednesday.

item.title: 2 Bases in Germany Placed on Heightened Alert Over Suspicious Episodes
item.description: The discovery led to the temporary lockdown of the base while the water supply was tested. NATO officials also reported that an intruder tried to forcibly enter one of the alliance’s bases in the country.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: The German military base in Cologne-Wahn was sealed off on Wednesday.

item.title: Ceasefire Talks on Sudan’s Civil War Open in Switzerland
item.description: The American-backed talks in Switzerland, which started on Wednesday, aim to halt a catastrophic civil war. But only one side has turned up.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recently arrived Sudanese refugees from the Darfur region wait in line to receive food on the outskirts of the Adré refugee camp, in Chad, last month.

item.title: Germany Issues Arrest Warrant for Ukrainian Over Nord Stream Explosion
item.description: The sabotage of the pipelines that carried Russian gas to Europe has become one of the central mysteries of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Danish Defence, via Agence France-Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Danish Defense Ministry of a vast swirl of bubbles on the surface of the Baltic Sea in international waters between Denmark and Sweden in September 2022.

item.title: China’s Extreme Fan Culture Makes Olympic Gold a Mixed Blessing
item.description: Fans have mobbed athletes in public and staked out their homes. State media outlets denounced their “visibly aggressive” behavior.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Ma Long, the captain of the Chinese men’s table tennis team, being greeted by fans at an airport after returning to Beijing on Monday. His team won gold at the Paris Olympics.

item.title: How Ukrainian Troops Invaded Russia
item.description: Planned in secrecy, the incursion was a bold move to upend the war’s dynamics and put Moscow on the defensive — a gambit that could also leave Ukraine exposed.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Constant Méheut, Alina Lobzina, Eric Schmitt and Sanjana Varghese
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military vehicle passing through a destroyed Russian border post this month.

item.title: Seven Pro-Palestinian Activists Charged Over Break-In at Israeli Arms Company’s U.K. Site
item.description: Prosecutors argued in court that pro-Palestinian activists had vandalized a site belonging to Elbit, an arms manufacturer, and had committed offenses with a “terrorist connection.”
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The entrance to the Elbit site near Bristol, in March. Last week, a protest group called Palestine Action broke into the building and smashed items inside. Police said its members also attacked officers and a security guard.

item.title: Tanzania Arrests 520 People in Mass Opposition Crackdown
item.description: The clampdown came after the police banned a youth rally and pointed to the anti-government protests that have swept neighboring Kenya in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Freeman Mbowe, the chairman of the Tanzanian opposition party Chadema, was among those arrested before a planned rally.

item.title: Where Students Run the Streets: Bangladesh in Limbo
item.description: The young protesters who felled an autocrat are now cabinet ministers and traffic cops, trying to restore order and chart a new future for a nation of 170 million.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Saif Hasnat and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Students managing traffic in Dhaka, Bangladesh. After Bangladesh’s iron-fisted leader, Sheikh Hasina, was toppled last week, almost all of the country’s police officers went into hiding.

item.title: What to Know About Mpox After the Global Health Emergency Alert
item.description: The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency over an outbreak that has spread to more than a dozen African countries.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: A Congolese health worker speaking with relatives and discharged patients about hygienic measures to follow after recovering from mpox last month near Goma, North Kivu Province.

item.title: W.H.O. Declares Global Emergency Over New Mpox Outbreak
item.description: The epidemic is concentrated in the Democratic Republic of Congo, but the virus has now appeared in a dozen other African countries.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A laboratory nurse, with samples taken from a patient with a suspected case of mpox near Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: Whimsical Parade of Banksy Animals Sends Fans on a Giddy Hunt
item.description: Each day for nine straight days, a new Banksy artwork appeared somewhere in London. For some, it became a citywide treasure hunt.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The eighth piece in a series by Banksy appeared on Monday in southeast London.

item.title: How Extreme Heat Is Threatening Education Progress Worldwide
item.description: Children today face many more extreme weather hazards that can undermine global gains in education.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Extreme heat in May closed some schools in the Philippines. Students did schoolwork near a Manila storefront.

item.title: New Zealand Charity Accidentally Gives Away Meth Disguised as Candy
item.description: Police were racing to recover the fake sweets, each of which contained up to 300 doses of methamphetamine. Three people sought medical attention.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The details of Ukraine’s military offensive.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military vehicle passing a destroyed Russian border post.

item.title: To Save the Panama Canal From Drought, a Disruptive Fix
item.description: In the wake of a drought that hampered shipping, the Panama Canal’s overseers are eager to expand water storage. Climate change leaves them no choice.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman and Federico Rios
item.media:description: Visitors at the Panama Canal, the economic heart of Panama.

item.title: Deadly Landslides in India Made Worse by Climate Change, Study Finds
item.description: Extreme rainfall made 10 percent heavier by human-caused climate change triggered landslides that killed hundreds, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:description: Rescuers searching through mud and debris after landslides in Wayanad district in Kerala, India, on Aug. 1.

item.title: Hunter Biden Sought State Department Help for Burisma
item.description: After President Biden dropped his re-election bid, his administration released records showing that while he was vice president, his son solicited U.S. government assistance.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The release of records came as Hunter Biden prepares to stand trial next month on charges of evading taxes on income from Burisma and other businesses.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Hamas Will Skip Upcoming Talks
item.description: Plus, in Russian territory captured by Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Protesters marched on Saturday for a cease-fire deal and to return Israeli hostages in Gaza.

item.title: Hamas Will Not Attend Gaza Cease-Fire Talks as Mediators Try to Secure Deal
item.description: Hopes for a breakthrough were damped after Hamas said it would not attend the peace talks set for Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Hwaida Saad and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians watching the aftermath of an Israeli airstrike in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Head of Panel That Ruled Against Jordan Chiles Represents Romania in Other Cases
item.description: The decision outraged U.S. Olympic and gymnastics officials, and led to a torrent of online abuse against both Chiles and Ana Barbosu, the Romanian athlete who ended up with the bronze.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jordan Chiles, right, with Simone Biles, left, and Rebeca Andrade after the floor exercise final last week in Paris.

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia: What to Know
item.description: The incursion caught Russia by surprise and signified a shift in tactics for Kyiv after more than two years of war with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Constant Méheut, Kim Barker, Anton Troianovski and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian men carrying a dead Russian soldier in a body bag after finding him in the rubble of a destroyed Russian border post on Monday.

item.title: Fires Near Athens Leave a Path of Destruction
item.description: The Greek authorities said the threat posed by the blazes had lessened as of Tuesday, thanks in part to an overnight lull in the strong winds. But the risk remained.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Walking through charred farmland in the area of Chalandri, northeast of Athens, on Tuesday.

item.title: On the 75th anniversary of the Geneva Conventions, the war in Gaza resonates.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A hospital staff member on Monday looking at the bodies of Palestinians inside the morgue at Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis, southern Gaza.

item.title: Israel Was Less Flexible in Recent Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, Documents Show
item.description: The country made five new demands, according to documents detailing its newest negotiating positions.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: The office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel denied that he had added new conditions and said that he had instead sought to clarify ambiguities in an earlier proposal.

item.title: Why China’s and Russia’s Militaries Are Training Together
item.description: The two countries have held joint exercises near Alaska, Taiwan and Japan in defiance of the United States and its alliances.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Russian military in July purporting to show U.S. and Canadian jet fighters near a Russian bomber during a joint patrol exercise with Chinese military planes near Alaska.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s response to a Ukrainian incursion.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Residents of an apartment building in Russia’s Kursk region that was damaged by shelling.

item.title: Rachael Lillis, Who Voiced Popular ‘Pokémon’ Characters, Dies at 55
item.description: Ms. Lillis voiced the characters of Misty and Jessie in the animated series based on a video game. She was diagnosed with breast cancer this year.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Rachael Lillis at Animate Florida in 2017.

item.title: Russian Border Post Reveals Signs of Ukraine’s Surprise Attack
item.description: A week after the biggest foreign incursion into Russia since World War II, The New York Times visited one of the spots where Ukrainian forces stormed into Russia and surprised the defenders.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The body of a dead Russian soldier lying in front of the destroyed Russian border post at Sudzha Border Crossing Monday. The body was recovered by the Ukrainian military, carried out of the bombed out building on a stretcher and later placed in a body bag.

item.title: Netanyahu Clashes With Defense Minister on Gaza, Exposing Schisms
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused Yoav Gallant of embracing an “anti-Israel narrative” in a disagreement over how to prosecute the war.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Isabel Kershner, Eric Schmitt and Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel criticized Defense Minister Yoav Gallant after Israeli news outlets reported that Mr. Gallant had disparaged the goal of achieving a “total victory” over Hamas.

item.title: Javad Zarif’s Resignation in Iran Signals Divisions as President’s Cabinet Takes Shape
item.description: Mohammad Javad Zarif’s resignation shocked Iran’s political circles and came as President Masoud Pezeshkian announced that his cabinet would include several conservatives and only one woman.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Masoud Pezeshkian, right, of Iran campaigning with Mohammad Javad Zarif in June. Mr. Zarif resigned from the government on Sunday.

item.title: Pakistan’s Ex-Spy Chief, an Imran Khan Ally, Is Arrested
item.description: Lt. Gen. Faiz Hameed is the first current or former head of the powerful Inter-Services Intelligence agency to face court-martial proceedings.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Putin Lashes Out Over Incursion
item.description: Plus, A.I. is helping piece together an ancient epic.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near the border with Russia on Sunday.

item.title: Why Iran Has Waited to Retaliate Against Israel for Hamas Leader’s Killing
item.description: Tehran is under pressure to avenge the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, but analysts said it is balancing multiple factors as it weighs a response.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck bearing Ismail Haniyeh’s coffin driving through Tehran this month.

item.title: Netanyahu Slams Gallant for Questioning the Goal of ‘Total Victory’ in Gaza
item.description: A strongly worded statement from the Israeli prime minister’s office accused Yoav Gallant, the defense minister, of harming the chances of reaching a hostage release deal.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, with his defense minister, Yoav Gallant, in October.

item.title: For the Rescuer of an Ancient Shipwreck, Trouble Arrived in the Mail
item.description: The packages were sent to a woman whose work had led to the heralded recovery of the Kyrenia, and to new insights into classical Greek seafaring. But their ancient contents were a problem.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley and Seamus Hughes
item.media:credit: Bildagentur-online/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: After it was recovered in the 1960s by a team that included Susan Womer Katzev and her husband, Michael, this well-preserved hull provided new insight into ancient sailing ships.

item.title: Man Arrested After Woman and Girl Stabbed in London’s Leicester Square
item.description: A girl, 11, was recovering in a hospital after being attacked on Monday. The police said her mother, initially thought to have been stabbed, had not been injured.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: James Manning/Press Association, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers guarding the site in Leicester Square in London where a girl was wounded in a knife attack on Monday.

item.title: Russia, Facing Ukrainian Incursion Into Kursk, Maintains Pressure in East
item.description: Russian forces are pummeling Ukrainian positions along the front lines, Ukrainian military officials said, as attacks on Russian soil by Ukraine continue.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Evelina Riabenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Ukrainian armored vehicle in the Sumy region, near the border with Russia, on Sunday.

item.title: U.K. Riots Pose Critical Test for Keir Starmer
item.description: Even after restoring order, the new prime minister faces a bigger challenge: defusing the issues of fraying public services and a cost of living crisis that underlie the unrest.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, left, visited a mosque this month in Solihull, England. Mosques were targeted as anti-immigrant riots fueled by disinformation spread across the country.

item.title: U.S. Officials to Visit China for Economic Talks as Trade Tensions Rise
item.description: The recently established U.S.-China Financial Working Group is set to meet for discussions about financial stability and curbing the flow of fentanyl.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Communication between the United States and China has improved over the past year, but the economic relationship remains fraught because of disagreements over industrial policy and green energy.

item.title: A Nazi Villa So Tainted Berlin Can’t Give It Away
item.description: The former estate of Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi propaganda minister, is too expensive to keep and perilous to sell. No one knows quite what to do with it.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors in May at the main entrance of Joseph Goebbels’s former villa near Wandlitz, Germany.

item.title: U.S. Orders Submarine to Middle East Amid Fears of Escalation
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, the Pentagon said. In an unusual disclosure, it said Mr. Austin had ordered a submarine to the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Spc. William Gore/U.S. Navy, via Reuters
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Georgia, a guided-missile submarine, in a 2020 photograph released by the U.S. Navy. The submarine is moving to the Middle East amid fears of an escalation in regional conflicts.

item.title: Wildfire Near Athens Spreads
item.description: The blaze broke out in a town near the Greek capital on Sunday, damaging buildings and prompting evacuations. Strong winds have helped the fire spread.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Mike Ives
item.media:description: A local resident evacuated during a wildfire in Dione, Greece, on Monday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and Tim Walz at a rally in Las Vegas on Saturday.

item.title: The Filipinos Living in the Shadow of China’s Military Might
item.description: More than 200 civilian settlers on a contested island in the South China Sea find themselves on the frontier of a possible conflict with China.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia and Jes Aznar
item.media:description: The runway on Thitu, which is occupied by the Philippines, with Chinese ships on the horizon, in June.

item.title: Tom Cruise Pulls Off a Stunt at Closing Ceremony
item.description: Cruise, one of Hollywood’s most well-known movie stars, rappelled down into the Stade de France, and the crowd of Olympians went wild as Paris handed over to the next Summer Games, in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Cruise attending a women’s gymnastics event in Paris.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Israel Widens Evacuation Orders
item.description: Plus, house calls for nomads.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Palestinians ordered to leave Khan Younis yesterday.

item.title: Why Did Jordan Chiles Lose a Bronze Medal?
item.description: An inquiry by Chiles’s coach led judges to adjust her score and give her a medal. A court ruled the inquiry came too late. Now, the I.O.C. wants her bronze back.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.category: United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jordan Chiles, right, with her teammate Simone Biles and Rebeca Andrade of Brazil after the floor exercise.

item.title: Olympic Marathon Course Lets Runners Inside the Ropes For a Night 10K
item.description: A public marathon and a series of overnight 10Ks offered recreational runners a chance to feel closer to the Games.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympic cauldron glowed over runners in the Marathon for All.

item.title: Sifan Hassan Wins Olympic Marathon, Testing Limits of Endurance
item.description: The Dutch Olympian added a victory in the longest race of the Games to her bronze medals in the 5,000 and 10,000 meters. “What was I thinking?” she said afterward.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: Sifan Hassan became the first person to win medals in track’s three longest distances at the Olympics since Emil Zatopek in 1952.

item.title: As Kenyan Police Force Deploys in Haiti, Gang Violence Shifts
item.description: Weeks after an international police force began arriving to take on gangs, armed groups are redirecting their campaign of terror outside the capital.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams and Andre Paultre
item.media:description: A contingent of Kenyan police officers arriving last month at Toussaint Louverture International Airport in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. At least six other countries have committed to providing more security forces.

item.title: Rethinking Tourism With the Renewal of a Beloved Italian Path
item.description: Officials hope the reopening of the Via dell’Amore will be an opportunity to rethink tourism in Cinque Terre, getting visitors off the beaten path.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Visitors at the entrance to the Via dell’Amore in Cinque Terre, on the Ligurian coast of Italy. The path reopened last month.

item.title: Ukraine’s Summer Camps Are Altered by War
item.description: As the once carefree summers of Ukrainian childhood and young adulthood are forever altered by war, traditional camps have taken on a more patriotic tone.
item.dc:creator: Diego Ibarra Sanchez and Megan Specia
